Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Consider throwing a ball
straight into the air. Can you predict the motion
of the ball after it leaves your hand? Sure, that's easy. The ball will move upward
until it gets to some highest point, then it will come back down
and land in your hand again. Of course, that's what happens, and you know this because you have
witnessed events like this countless times. You've been observing the physics
of everyday phenomena your entire life. But suppose we explore a question
about the physics of atoms, like what does the motion of an electron around the nucleus of a 
hydrogen atom look like? Could we answer that question based on
our experience with everyday physics? Definietly not. Why? Because the physics that governs the
behavior of systems at such small scales is much different than the physics
of the macroscopic objects you see around you all the time. The everyday world you know and love behaves according to the laws 
of classical mechanics. But systems on the scale of atoms behave according to the laws 
of quantum mechanics. This quantum world turns out to be
a very strange place. An illustration of quantum strangeness
is given by a famous thought experiment: Schrödinger's cat. A physicist, who doesn't particularly 
like cats, puts a cat in a box, along with a bomb that has a 50% chance
of blowing up after the lid is closed. Until we reopen the lid,
there is no way of knowing whether the bomb exploded or not, and thus, no way of knowing
if the cat is alive or dead. In quantum physics,
we could say that before our observation the cat was in a superposition state. It was neither alive nor dead but
rather in a mixture of both possibilities, with a 50% chance for each. The same sort of thing happens
to physical systems at quantum scales, like an electron orbiting
in a hydrogen atom. The electron isn't really orbiting at all. It's sort of everywhere in space,
all at once, with more of a probability of being
at some places than others, and it's only after 
we measure its position that we can pinpoint where it is
at that moment. A lot like how we didn't know
whether the cat was alive or dead until we opened the box. This brings us to the strange
and beautiful phenomenon of quantum entanglement. Suppose that instead of one cat in a box,
we have two cats in two different boxes. If we repeat the Schrödinger's cat experiment
with this pair of cats, the outcome of the experiment
can be one of four possibilities. Either both cats will be alive,
or both will be dead, or one will be alive 
and the other dead, or vice versa. The system of both cats
is again in a superposition state, with each outcome having a 25% chance
rather than 50%. But here's the cool thing: quantum mechanics tells us
it's possible to erase the both cats alive and both cats dead
outcomes from the superposition state. In other words,
there can be a two cat system, such that the outcome will always be
one cat alive and the other cat dead. The technical term for this is that the
states of the cats are entangled. But there's something truly mindblowing
about quantum entanglement. If you prepare the system of two cats
in boxes in this entangled state, then move the boxes to opposite 
ends of the universe, the outcome of the experiment
will still always be the same. One cat will always come out alive,
and the other cat will always end up dead, even though which particular cat
lives or dies is completely undetermined before we measure the outcome. How is this possible? How is it that the states of cats
on opposite sides of the universe can be entangled in this way? They're too far away to communicate
with each other in time, so how do the two bombs always 
conspire such that one blows up and the other doesn't? You might be thinking, "This is just some theoretical
mumbo jumbo. This sort of thing can't happen
in the real world." But it turns out that quantum entanglement has been confirmed in 
real world lab experiments. Two subatomic particles entangled
in a superposition state, where if one spins one way
then the other must spin the other way, will do just that,
even when there's no way for information to pass
from one particle to the other indicating which way to spin
to obey the rules of entanglement. It's not surprising then that
entanglement is at the core of quantum information science, a growing field studying how to use
the laws of the strange quantum world in our macroscopic world, like in quantum cryptography, so spies
can send secure messages to each other, or quantum computing,
for cracking secret codes. Everyday physics may start to look
a bit more like the strange quantum world. Quantum teleportation 
may even progress so far, that one day your cat will 
escape to a safer galaxy, where there are no physicists
and no boxes.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Systems on atomic scales behave according to the laws of:
Options: A. Optics, B. Classical mechanics, C. Statistical mechanics, D. Quantum mechanics, E. Calculus
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the predicted motion of a ball thrown straight into the air after it leaves the hand? Options: A. It moves downward immediately, B. It moves upward until it reaches its highest point, then comes back down, C. It stays suspended in mid-air, D. It follows a curved trajectory Correct Option: B
Question 2: Why can't our experience with everyday physics be used to predict the motion of an electron around the nucleus of a hydrogen atom? Options: A. Because the physics of atoms is more complex than the physics of macroscopic objects, B. Because the physics of atoms is governed by different laws than the physics of macroscopic objects, C. Because electrons are too small to observe, D. Because atoms are too far away to study Correct Option: B
Question 3: In the thought experiment of Schrödinger's cat, what is the state of the cat before the box is opened? Options: A. Alive, B. Dead, C. In a superposition state, both alive and dead, D. In a state of limbo Correct Option: C
Question 4: According to quantum physics, what is the nature of an electron's position in a hydrogen atom? Options: A. It orbits the nucleus in a fixed path, B. It is everywhere in space, with a higher probability of being in certain places, C. It jumps between different energy levels, D. It stays in one fixed position Correct Option: B
Question 5: If two cats are placed in two different boxes and the Schrödinger's cat experiment is repeated, what are the possible outcomes? Options: A. Both cats alive, both cats dead, B. One cat alive, one cat dead, C. Both cats alive, both cats dead, one cat alive and one cat dead, or vice versa, D. Only one cat can be alive Correct Option: C
Question 6: What phenomenon describes the connection between two particles such that the state of one particle affects the state of the other, even if they are separated by large distances? Options: A. Quantum superposition, B. Quantum entanglement, C. Classical mechanics, D. Wave-particle duality Correct Option: B
Question 7: If two subatomic particles are entangled in a superposition state, what will happen if one particle spins one way? Options: A. The other particle will spin the same way, B. The other particle will spin the opposite way, C. The other particle will not spin at all, D. The other particle will change its spin randomly Correct Option: B
Question 8: What are some potential applications of quantum entanglement in quantum information science? Options: A. Quantum cryptography, B. Quantum computing, C. Quantum teleportation, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 9: Why is quantum entanglement considered "mind-blowing"? Options: A. Because it allows for faster-than-light communication, B. Because it allows for the manipulation of particles at a distance, C. Because it shows that the states of particles can be connected even when separated by large distances, D. Because it is a theoretical concept with no practical applications Correct Option: C
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is a potential future development in quantum teleportation? Options: A. Teleporting objects from one location to another, B. Teleporting information from one location to another, C. Escaping to a safer galaxy, D. Sending secure messages over long distances Correct Option: C

**Transcript**:
Consider throwing a ball
straight into the air. Can you predict the motion
of the ball after it leaves your hand? Sure, that's easy. The ball will move upward
until it gets to some highest point, then it will come back down
and land in your hand again. Of course, that's what happens, and you know this because you have
witnessed events like this countless times. You've been observing the physics
of everyday phenomena your entire life. But suppose we explore a question
about the physics of atoms, like what does the motion of an electron around the nucleus of a 
hydrogen atom look like? Could we answer that question based on
our experience with everyday physics? Definietly not. Why? Because the physics that governs the
behavior of systems at such small scales is much different than the physics
of the macroscopic objects you see around you all the time. The everyday world you know and love behaves according to the laws 
of classical mechanics. But systems on the scale of atoms behave according to the laws 
of quantum mechanics. This quantum world turns out to be
a very strange place. An illustration of quantum strangeness
is given by a famous thought experiment: Schrödinger's cat. A physicist, who doesn't particularly 
like cats, puts a cat in a box, along with a bomb that has a 50% chance
of blowing up after the lid is closed. Until we reopen the lid,
there is no way of knowing whether the bomb exploded or not, and thus, no way of knowing
if the cat is alive or dead. In quantum physics,
we could say that before our observation the cat was in a superposition state. It was neither alive nor dead but
rather in a mixture of both possibilities, with a 50% chance for each. The same sort of thing happens
to physical systems at quantum scales, like an electron orbiting
in a hydrogen atom. The electron isn't really orbiting at all. It's sort of everywhere in space,
all at once, with more of a probability of being
at some places than others, and it's only after 
we measure its position that we can pinpoint where it is
at that moment. A lot like how we didn't know
whether the cat was alive or dead until we opened the box. This brings us to the strange
and beautiful phenomenon of quantum entanglement. Suppose that instead of one cat in a box,
we have two cats in two different boxes. If we repeat the Schrödinger's cat experiment
with this pair of cats, the outcome of the experiment
can be one of four possibilities. Either both cats will be alive,
or both will be dead, or one will be alive 
and the other dead, or vice versa. The system of both cats
is again in a superposition state, with each outcome having a 25% chance
rather than 50%. But here's the cool thing: quantum mechanics tells us
it's possible to erase the both cats alive and both cats dead
outcomes from the superposition state. In other words,
there can be a two cat system, such that the outcome will always be
one cat alive and the other cat dead. The technical term for this is that the
states of the cats are entangled. But there's something truly mindblowing
about quantum entanglement. If you prepare the system of two cats
in boxes in this entangled state, then move the boxes to opposite 
ends of the universe, the outcome of the experiment
will still always be the same. One cat will always come out alive,
and the other cat will always end up dead, even though which particular cat
lives or dies is completely undetermined before we measure the outcome. How is this possible? How is it that the states of cats
on opposite sides of the universe can be entangled in this way? They're too far away to communicate
with each other in time, so how do the two bombs always 
conspire such that one blows up and the other doesn't? You might be thinking, "This is just some theoretical
mumbo jumbo. This sort of thing can't happen
in the real world." But it turns out that quantum entanglement has been confirmed in 
real world lab experiments. Two subatomic particles entangled
in a superposition state, where if one spins one way
then the other must spin the other way, will do just that,
even when there's no way for information to pass
from one particle to the other indicating which way to spin
to obey the rules of entanglement. It's not surprising then that
entanglement is at the core of quantum information science, a growing field studying how to use
the laws of the strange quantum world in our macroscopic world, like in quantum cryptography, so spies
can send secure messages to each other, or quantum computing,
for cracking secret codes. Everyday physics may start to look
a bit more like the strange quantum world. Quantum teleportation 
may even progress so far, that one day your cat will 
escape to a safer galaxy, where there are no physicists
and no boxes.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In the Schrodinger’s cat experiment, before its state is observed the cat is in a:
Options: A. Hyperposition state, B. Ultraposition state, C. Superlocation state, D. Echolocation state, E. Superposition state
Correct Option: E

Both questions ask about the state of the cat in the Schrödinger's cat experiment before its state is observed, and both have an option that correctly identifies the cat as being in a superposition state. 

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 3.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Consider throwing a ball
straight into the air. Can you predict the motion
of the ball after it leaves your hand? Sure, that's easy. The ball will move upward
until it gets to some highest point, then it will come back down
and land in your hand again. Of course, that's what happens, and you know this because you have
witnessed events like this countless times. You've been observing the physics
of everyday phenomena your entire life. But suppose we explore a question
about the physics of atoms, like what does the motion of an electron around the nucleus of a 
hydrogen atom look like? Could we answer that question based on
our experience with everyday physics? Definietly not. Why? Because the physics that governs the
behavior of systems at such small scales is much different than the physics
of the macroscopic objects you see around you all the time. The everyday world you know and love behaves according to the laws 
of classical mechanics. But systems on the scale of atoms behave according to the laws 
of quantum mechanics. This quantum world turns out to be
a very strange place. An illustration of quantum strangeness
is given by a famous thought experiment: Schrödinger's cat. A physicist, who doesn't particularly 
like cats, puts a cat in a box, along with a bomb that has a 50% chance
of blowing up after the lid is closed. Until we reopen the lid,
there is no way of knowing whether the bomb exploded or not, and thus, no way of knowing
if the cat is alive or dead. In quantum physics,
we could say that before our observation the cat was in a superposition state. It was neither alive nor dead but
rather in a mixture of both possibilities, with a 50% chance for each. The same sort of thing happens
to physical systems at quantum scales, like an electron orbiting
in a hydrogen atom. The electron isn't really orbiting at all. It's sort of everywhere in space,
all at once, with more of a probability of being
at some places than others, and it's only after 
we measure its position that we can pinpoint where it is
at that moment. A lot like how we didn't know
whether the cat was alive or dead until we opened the box. This brings us to the strange
and beautiful phenomenon of quantum entanglement. Suppose that instead of one cat in a box,
we have two cats in two different boxes. If we repeat the Schrödinger's cat experiment
with this pair of cats, the outcome of the experiment
can be one of four possibilities. Either both cats will be alive,
or both will be dead, or one will be alive 
and the other dead, or vice versa. The system of both cats
is again in a superposition state, with each outcome having a 25% chance
rather than 50%. But here's the cool thing: quantum mechanics tells us
it's possible to erase the both cats alive and both cats dead
outcomes from the superposition state. In other words,
there can be a two cat system, such that the outcome will always be
one cat alive and the other cat dead. The technical term for this is that the
states of the cats are entangled. But there's something truly mindblowing
about quantum entanglement. If you prepare the system of two cats
in boxes in this entangled state, then move the boxes to opposite 
ends of the universe, the outcome of the experiment
will still always be the same. One cat will always come out alive,
and the other cat will always end up dead, even though which particular cat
lives or dies is completely undetermined before we measure the outcome. How is this possible? How is it that the states of cats
on opposite sides of the universe can be entangled in this way? They're too far away to communicate
with each other in time, so how do the two bombs always 
conspire such that one blows up and the other doesn't? You might be thinking, "This is just some theoretical
mumbo jumbo. This sort of thing can't happen
in the real world." But it turns out that quantum entanglement has been confirmed in 
real world lab experiments. Two subatomic particles entangled
in a superposition state, where if one spins one way
then the other must spin the other way, will do just that,
even when there's no way for information to pass
from one particle to the other indicating which way to spin
to obey the rules of entanglement. It's not surprising then that
entanglement is at the core of quantum information science, a growing field studying how to use
the laws of the strange quantum world in our macroscopic world, like in quantum cryptography, so spies
can send secure messages to each other, or quantum computing,
for cracking secret codes. Everyday physics may start to look
a bit more like the strange quantum world. Quantum teleportation 
may even progress so far, that one day your cat will 
escape to a safer galaxy, where there are no physicists
and no boxes.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In the version of the Schrodinger’s cat experiment with two cats in which one of the cats always comes out alive and the other cat always comes out dead, we say that the states of the cats are said to be:
Options: A. Intertwined, B. Conjoined, C. Tangled, D. Entangled, E. Bojangled
Correct Option: D

Question 1: What is the predicted motion of a ball thrown straight into the air after it leaves the hand? Options: A. It moves downward immediately, B. It moves upward until it reaches its highest point, then comes back down, C. It stays suspended in mid-air, D. It follows a curved trajectory Correct Option: B
Question 2: Why can't our experience with everyday physics be used to predict the motion of an electron around the nucleus of a hydrogen atom? Options: A. Because the physics of atoms is more complex than the physics of macroscopic objects, B. Because the physics of atoms is governed by different laws than the physics of macroscopic objects, C. Because electrons are too small to observe, D. Because atoms are too far away to study Correct Option: B
Question 3: In the thought experiment of Schrödinger's cat, what is the state of the cat before the box is opened? Options: A. Alive, B. Dead, C. In a superposition state, both alive and dead, D. In a state of limbo Correct Option: C
Question 4: According to quantum physics, what is the nature of an electron's position in a hydrogen atom? Options: A. It orbits the nucleus in a fixed path, B. It is everywhere in space, with a higher probability of being in certain places, C. It jumps between different energy levels, D. It stays in one fixed position Correct Option: B
Question 5: If two cats are placed in two different boxes and the Schrödinger's cat experiment is repeated, what are the possible outcomes? Options: A. Both cats alive, both cats dead, B. One cat alive, one cat dead, C. Both cats alive, both cats dead, one cat alive and one cat dead, or vice versa, D. Only one cat can be alive Correct Option: C
Question 6: What phenomenon describes the connection between two particles such that the state of one particle affects the state of the other, even if they are separated by large distances? Options: A. Quantum superposition, B. Quantum entanglement, C. Classical mechanics, D. Wave-particle duality Correct Option: B
Question 7: If two subatomic particles are entangled in a superposition state, what will happen if one particle spins one way? Options: A. The other particle will spin the same way, B. The other particle will spin the opposite way, C. The other particle will not spin at all, D. The other particle will change its spin randomly Correct Option: B
Question 8: What are some potential applications of quantum entanglement in quantum information science? Options: A. Quantum cryptography, B. Quantum computing, C. Quantum teleportation, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 9: Why is quantum entanglement considered "mind-blowing"? Options: A. Because it allows for faster-than-light communication, B. Because it allows for the manipulation of particles at a distance, C. Because it shows that the states of particles can be connected even when separated by large distances, D. Because it is a theoretical concept with no practical applications Correct Option: C
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is a potential future development in quantum teleportation? Options: A. Teleporting objects from one location to another, B. Teleporting information from one location to another, C. Escaping to a safer galaxy, D. Sending secure messages over long distances Correct Option: C

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Both questions are about the phenomenon of entanglement in quantum physics, and both ask about the term used to describe the connection between two particles or cats. The correct option in both questions is related to entanglement (D. Entangled in the ground truth MCQ and B. Quantum entanglement in Question 6).

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Consider throwing a ball
straight into the air. Can you predict the motion
of the ball after it leaves your hand? Sure, that's easy. The ball will move upward
until it gets to some highest point, then it will come back down
and land in your hand again. Of course, that's what happens, and you know this because you have
witnessed events like this countless times. You've been observing the physics
of everyday phenomena your entire life. But suppose we explore a question
about the physics of atoms, like what does the motion of an electron around the nucleus of a 
hydrogen atom look like? Could we answer that question based on
our experience with everyday physics? Definietly not. Why? Because the physics that governs the
behavior of systems at such small scales is much different than the physics
of the macroscopic objects you see around you all the time. The everyday world you know and love behaves according to the laws 
of classical mechanics. But systems on the scale of atoms behave according to the laws 
of quantum mechanics. This quantum world turns out to be
a very strange place. An illustration of quantum strangeness
is given by a famous thought experiment: Schrödinger's cat. A physicist, who doesn't particularly 
like cats, puts a cat in a box, along with a bomb that has a 50% chance
of blowing up after the lid is closed. Until we reopen the lid,
there is no way of knowing whether the bomb exploded or not, and thus, no way of knowing
if the cat is alive or dead. In quantum physics,
we could say that before our observation the cat was in a superposition state. It was neither alive nor dead but
rather in a mixture of both possibilities, with a 50% chance for each. The same sort of thing happens
to physical systems at quantum scales, like an electron orbiting
in a hydrogen atom. The electron isn't really orbiting at all. It's sort of everywhere in space,
all at once, with more of a probability of being
at some places than others, and it's only after 
we measure its position that we can pinpoint where it is
at that moment. A lot like how we didn't know
whether the cat was alive or dead until we opened the box. This brings us to the strange
and beautiful phenomenon of quantum entanglement. Suppose that instead of one cat in a box,
we have two cats in two different boxes. If we repeat the Schrödinger's cat experiment
with this pair of cats, the outcome of the experiment
can be one of four possibilities. Either both cats will be alive,
or both will be dead, or one will be alive 
and the other dead, or vice versa. The system of both cats
is again in a superposition state, with each outcome having a 25% chance
rather than 50%. But here's the cool thing: quantum mechanics tells us
it's possible to erase the both cats alive and both cats dead
outcomes from the superposition state. In other words,
there can be a two cat system, such that the outcome will always be
one cat alive and the other cat dead. The technical term for this is that the
states of the cats are entangled. But there's something truly mindblowing
about quantum entanglement. If you prepare the system of two cats
in boxes in this entangled state, then move the boxes to opposite 
ends of the universe, the outcome of the experiment
will still always be the same. One cat will always come out alive,
and the other cat will always end up dead, even though which particular cat
lives or dies is completely undetermined before we measure the outcome. How is this possible? How is it that the states of cats
on opposite sides of the universe can be entangled in this way? They're too far away to communicate
with each other in time, so how do the two bombs always 
conspire such that one blows up and the other doesn't? You might be thinking, "This is just some theoretical
mumbo jumbo. This sort of thing can't happen
in the real world." But it turns out that quantum entanglement has been confirmed in 
real world lab experiments. Two subatomic particles entangled
in a superposition state, where if one spins one way
then the other must spin the other way, will do just that,
even when there's no way for information to pass
from one particle to the other indicating which way to spin
to obey the rules of entanglement. It's not surprising then that
entanglement is at the core of quantum information science, a growing field studying how to use
the laws of the strange quantum world in our macroscopic world, like in quantum cryptography, so spies
can send secure messages to each other, or quantum computing,
for cracking secret codes. Everyday physics may start to look
a bit more like the strange quantum world. Quantum teleportation 
may even progress so far, that one day your cat will 
escape to a safer galaxy, where there are no physicists
and no boxes.

Options: A. 10 meters apart, B. 100 meters apart, C. 1 million miles apart, D. Distance doesn't affect the result, E. Outside of Dexter's lab
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Well 'Let's Make a Deal' was a popular show back in the day; contestants could go on this game show and maybe go home with the car of their dreams. First of all the game show host was a very famous guy named Monty Hall. And Monty would come on to the show and he would have three doors. And a contestant, that's you, would come on to the show, Monty would give you the chance to choose door number 1, door number 2 or door number 3. Now behind one of those doors, only one, was your dream flash car. Bright red, sports car, very fast; it was awesome. And behind the other two doors were 'zonks', that was the 
'Let's Make a Deal' word for something that you don't really want. So you had- looks like a 1 in 3 chance of getting your dream car. So suppose you pick door number 1; and Monty would then do the same thing every week. He would go over to the two doors you didn't pick, 2 and 3, and he would open one of them. Let's suppose he opened door number 2. And the door that Monty opened would always have behind it a zonk. 
- (So- so he knew?) Well he knows everything right? He's the game show host. And then Monty looked at you in the face and say, 'do you like door number 1 or do you want to switch?' There's only one thing to switch to, in this case it's door number 3. Are you gonna stay with your choice, or are you gonna make that leap to something different? And very often contestants would stand there agonised, right? So they've got some new information- 
- (So stick or switch?) Stick or switch. Well, a remarkable thing about this problem, simple as it is, is that it has sparked just endless debate. In the time of the show I don't recall anybody ever saying there was a dedicated strategy that you should always follow, but in fact there is a dedicated strategy should follow: you should pick door number 3. That's the answer, you should switch. You should switch every time and that will do the best for you over the long run. So there is a 1/3 chance that the car is behind the door you picked initially, that means there must be a 2/3 chance, much greater twice as big, that the car is somewhere else. And since we know that somewhere else cannot be door number 2, because Monty showed us that, it's got to be over here. So this is what you should choose, you should switch. Twice as likely to have the car behind the door that you didn't pick as the door that you did. 2/3 probability to a 1/3 probability. Now if you switch are you guaranteed to win? Absolutely not. But if you play this game over and over again, on average, you will win 2/3 of the time so switch is your strategy and you can't beat it. One thing that you might say is that the initial 2/3 chance that the car was behind door number 2 and door number 3 got concentrated behind the door that Monty did not open. That's effectively what's happening, that's intuitively what's happening, and that in fact is what the mathematics shows is happening. Now there is a way to see that in kind of a more grand way; if we imagine not having three doors but we imagine having a hundred doors. And let's imagine that we're playing the same kind of game, we have Monty over here, he is going to give you an opportunity to pick a door and your dream flash car is behind one of these hundred doors but there are 99 zonks all behind the other doors. Now what is it that you're going to do? Well you're going to pick a door, say again you pick door number 1. Now you're feeling a little bit different than you might have felt in the case where there were three doors; because there you thought, wow I've got a 1 in 3 chance. Here you're thinking I've got a 1 in 100 chance,
I'm not gonna get that car. It's not behind door number 1, it's probably behind one of the other 99 doors. What Monty does is he opens 98 of those 99 doors, he shows you 98 zonks and he asked you now, do you want to switch? Well maybe just because of the sheer numbers this thing is a little clearer. You know that there was 99 out of a 100 chance that the car was over here and now the only door you're left with after Monty shows you all those zonks 
is door, say, number 37. And you're thinking, this is no good, this is no good, all those doors are no good; do I want to stay with 1 or do I want to stay with 37? You can sort of almost feel the concentration of that 99 percent going behind door number 37 and so you switch over here and very likely you're gonna get that car and drive away. (I like your car drawing.) Well thank you! (That makes more sense doesn't it? 
Suddenly it) (seems like a no-brainer.)
- It does seem like a no-brainer but in fact when it's on a smaller scale, maybe just because 1/3 and 2/3 are a whole lot closer to each other than 1 in 100 and 99 in a 100, that the the point is is obscured. [Preview] X and Y is the probability
of X given that Y happens, given that you know you open door number 2, what's the probability of the cars there, times the probability of Y happening by itself.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: True or False: Monty Hall reveals a goat behind one of the doors. Staying with your original door gives you a 50 percent chance of winning the car.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who hosted the popular game show "Let's Make a Deal"? Options: A. Monty Hall, B. Bob Barker, C. Drew Carey, D. Ryan Seacrest Correct Option: A
Question 2: What term was used on "Let's Make a Deal" to describe an undesirable prize? Options: A. Zonk, B. Lemon, C. Dud, D. Flop Correct Option: A
Question 3: In the Monty Hall problem, what is the probability that the car is behind the door initially chosen by the contestant? Options: A. 1/2, B. 1/3, C. 2/3, D. 3/4 Correct Option: B
Question 4: If the contestant switches doors after Monty opens one of the other two doors, what is the probability that they will win the car? Options: A. 1/2, B. 1/3, C. 2/3, D. 3/4 Correct Option: C
Question 5: Why is it advantageous for the contestant to switch doors? Options: A. The probability of the car being behind the initial door is higher than the probability of it being behind the other door., B. The probability of the car being behind the initial door is lower than the probability of it being behind the other door., C. Monty's action of opening one of the other doors does not provide any new information., D. The contestant has a 50-50 chance of winning regardless of which door they choose. Correct Option: B
Question 6: Imagine you are a contestant on "Let's Make a Deal" and you initially choose door number 1. Monty then opens door number 2, revealing a zonk. What should you do next? Options: A. Stick with door number 1, B. Switch to door number 3, C. Ask Monty for a hint, D. Refuse to play Correct Option: B
Question 7: In a scenario with 100 doors, what is the probability that the car is behind the door initially chosen by the contestant? Options: A. 1/10, B. 1/50, C. 1/100, D. 1/200 Correct Option: C
Question 8: In a scenario with 100 doors, if the contestant switches doors after Monty opens 98 of the other 99 doors, what is the probability that they will win the car? Options: A. 1/2, B. 1/10, C. 99/100, D. 1/100 Correct Option: C
Question 9: What key insight can be gained from considering a scenario with 100 doors in the Monty Hall problem? Options: A. The probability of the car being behind the initial door is higher than the probability of it being behind the other door., B. The probability of the car being behind the initial door is much lower than the probability of it being behind one of the other 99 doors., C. The contestant should always stick with their initial choice., D. The probability of winning remains the same regardless of the number of doors. Correct Option: B
Question 10: What mathematical concept underlies the Monty Hall problem? Options: A. Conditional probability, B. Bayes' theorem, C. Expected value, D. Random walk Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5. 

This question addresses the core concept of the Monty Hall problem, which is the advantage of switching doors due to the probability of the car being behind the initial door being lower than the probability of it being behind the other door. This aligns with the ground truth MCQ's focus on the false assumption that staying with the original door gives a 50% chance of winning.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 5

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Well 'Let's Make a Deal' was a popular show back in the day; contestants could go on this game show and maybe go home with the car of their dreams. First of all the game show host was a very famous guy named Monty Hall. And Monty would come on to the show and he would have three doors. And a contestant, that's you, would come on to the show, Monty would give you the chance to choose door number 1, door number 2 or door number 3. Now behind one of those doors, only one, was your dream flash car. Bright red, sports car, very fast; it was awesome. And behind the other two doors were 'zonks', that was the 
'Let's Make a Deal' word for something that you don't really want. So you had- looks like a 1 in 3 chance of getting your dream car. So suppose you pick door number 1; and Monty would then do the same thing every week. He would go over to the two doors you didn't pick, 2 and 3, and he would open one of them. Let's suppose he opened door number 2. And the door that Monty opened would always have behind it a zonk. 
- (So- so he knew?) Well he knows everything right? He's the game show host. And then Monty looked at you in the face and say, 'do you like door number 1 or do you want to switch?' There's only one thing to switch to, in this case it's door number 3. Are you gonna stay with your choice, or are you gonna make that leap to something different? And very often contestants would stand there agonised, right? So they've got some new information- 
- (So stick or switch?) Stick or switch. Well, a remarkable thing about this problem, simple as it is, is that it has sparked just endless debate. In the time of the show I don't recall anybody ever saying there was a dedicated strategy that you should always follow, but in fact there is a dedicated strategy should follow: you should pick door number 3. That's the answer, you should switch. You should switch every time and that will do the best for you over the long run. So there is a 1/3 chance that the car is behind the door you picked initially, that means there must be a 2/3 chance, much greater twice as big, that the car is somewhere else. And since we know that somewhere else cannot be door number 2, because Monty showed us that, it's got to be over here. So this is what you should choose, you should switch. Twice as likely to have the car behind the door that you didn't pick as the door that you did. 2/3 probability to a 1/3 probability. Now if you switch are you guaranteed to win? Absolutely not. But if you play this game over and over again, on average, you will win 2/3 of the time so switch is your strategy and you can't beat it. One thing that you might say is that the initial 2/3 chance that the car was behind door number 2 and door number 3 got concentrated behind the door that Monty did not open. That's effectively what's happening, that's intuitively what's happening, and that in fact is what the mathematics shows is happening. Now there is a way to see that in kind of a more grand way; if we imagine not having three doors but we imagine having a hundred doors. And let's imagine that we're playing the same kind of game, we have Monty over here, he is going to give you an opportunity to pick a door and your dream flash car is behind one of these hundred doors but there are 99 zonks all behind the other doors. Now what is it that you're going to do? Well you're going to pick a door, say again you pick door number 1. Now you're feeling a little bit different than you might have felt in the case where there were three doors; because there you thought, wow I've got a 1 in 3 chance. Here you're thinking I've got a 1 in 100 chance,
I'm not gonna get that car. It's not behind door number 1, it's probably behind one of the other 99 doors. What Monty does is he opens 98 of those 99 doors, he shows you 98 zonks and he asked you now, do you want to switch? Well maybe just because of the sheer numbers this thing is a little clearer. You know that there was 99 out of a 100 chance that the car was over here and now the only door you're left with after Monty shows you all those zonks 
is door, say, number 37. And you're thinking, this is no good, this is no good, all those doors are no good; do I want to stay with 1 or do I want to stay with 37? You can sort of almost feel the concentration of that 99 percent going behind door number 37 and so you switch over here and very likely you're gonna get that car and drive away. (I like your car drawing.) Well thank you! (That makes more sense doesn't it? 
Suddenly it) (seems like a no-brainer.)
- It does seem like a no-brainer but in fact when it's on a smaller scale, maybe just because 1/3 and 2/3 are a whole lot closer to each other than 1 in 100 and 99 in a 100, that the the point is is obscured. [Preview] X and Y is the probability
of X given that Y happens, given that you know you open door number 2, what's the probability of the cars there, times the probability of Y happening by itself.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. 1/2, B. 2/3, C. 1/3, D. 3/4
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Imagine if half the people
in your neighborhood, your city, or even your whole country were wiped out. It might sound like something
out of an apocalyptic horror film, but it actually happened 
in the 14th century during a disease outbreak
known as the Black Death. Spreading from China through Asia,
the Middle East, Africa, and Europe, the devastating epidemic destroyed 
as much as 1/5 of the world's population, killing nearly 50% of Europeans
in just four years. One of the most fascinating
and puzzling things abut the Black Death is that the illness itself
was not a new phenomenon but one that has affected
humans for centuries. DNA analysis of bone
and tooth samples from this period, as well as an earlier epidemic known
as the Plague of Justinian in 541 CE, has revealed that both were caused
by Yersinia pestis, the same bacterium that causes
bubonic plague today. What this means is that the same disease
caused by the same pathogen can behave and spread 
very differently throughout history. Even before the use of antibiotics,
the deadliest oubreaks in modern times, such as the ones that occurred
in early 20th century India, killed no more than 3% of the population. Modern instances of plague
also tend to remain localized, or travel slowly,
as they are spread by rodent fleas. But the medieval Black Death,
which spread like wildfire, was most likely communicated directly
from one person to another. And because genetic comparisons of ancient
to modern strains of Yersinia pestis have not revealed any significantly
functional genetic differences, the key to why the earlier outbreak
was so much deadlier must lie not in the parasite but the host. For about 300 years during
the High Middle Ages, a warmer climate
and agricultural improvements had led to explosive population growth
throughout Europe. But with so many new mouths to feed, the end of this warm period
spelled disaster. High fertility rates
combined with reduced harvest, meant the land could no longer 
support its population, while the abundant supply of labor
kept wages low. As a result, most Europeans
in the early 14th century experienced a steady decline
in living standards, marked by famine, poverty and poor health,
leaving them vulnerable to infection. And indeed, the skeletal remains
of Black Death victims found in London show telltale signs of 
malnutrition and prior illness. The destruction caused by the Black Death
changed humanity in two important ways. On a societal level,
the rapid loss of population led to important changes
in Europe’s economic conditions. With more food to go around, as well as more land and better pay
for the surviving farmers and workers, people began to eat better and live longer as studies of London cemeteries
have shown. Higher living standards also brought
an increase in social mobility, weakening feudalism and eventually
leading to political reforms. But the plague also had an important
biological impact. The sudden death of so many of
the most frail and vulnerable people left behind a population with
a significantly different gene pool, including genes that may have helped
survivors resist the disease. And because such mutations 
often confer immunities to multiple pathogens 
that work in similar ways, research to discover the genetic
consequences of the Black Death has the potential to be hugely beneficial. Today, the threat of an epidemic 
on the scale of the Black Death has been largely eliminated 
thanks to antibiotics. But the bubonic plague continues to kill a
few thousand people worldwide every year, and the recent emergence
of a drug-resistant strain threatens the return of darker times. Learning more about the causes and effects
of the Black Death is important, not just for understanding how
our world has been shaped by the past. It may also help save us from 
a similar nightmare in the future.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What caused the Black Death?
Options: A. The smallpox virus, B. The influenza virus, C. Bubonic plague bacterium, D. The tuberculosis bacterium, E. No one knows
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What percentage of the world's population is estimated to have been destroyed by the Black Death in the 14th century? Options: A. 10%, B. 15%, C. 1/5 (or 20%), D. 25% Correct Option: C
Question 2: What was the primary cause of the Black Death, as revealed by DNA analysis of bone and tooth samples? Options: A. A new strain of the influenza virus, B. Yersinia pestis, the bacterium that causes bubonic plague, C. A genetic mutation in the human population, D. Poor sanitation and hygiene practices Correct Option: B
Question 3: How did the medieval Black Death likely spread, compared to modern instances of plague? Options: A. Through rodent fleas, B. Directly from one person to another, C. Through contaminated water sources, D. Through airborne transmission Correct Option: B
Question 4: What factor contributed to the rapid spread and high mortality rate of the Black Death in Europe? Options: A. A colder climate, B. Improved agricultural practices, C. High fertility rates combined with reduced harvests, D. Overcrowding in urban areas Correct Option: C
Question 5: What was the impact of the Black Death on the economic conditions in Europe? Options: A. It led to a decline in living standards and increased poverty, B. It resulted in a significant increase in social mobility and weakened feudalism, C. It had no significant impact on the economy, D. It led to a decrease in food production and availability Correct Option: B
Question 6: How did the Black Death affect the gene pool of the surviving population? Options: A. It resulted in a loss of genetic diversity, B. It led to an increase in genetic mutations that conferred immunity to multiple pathogens, C. It had no significant impact on the gene pool, D. It resulted in a decrease in the frequency of genes associated with disease resistance Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is a potential benefit of researching the genetic consequences of the Black Death? Options: A. It may lead to the development of new antibiotics, B. It may help us understand how to prevent future pandemics, C. It may reveal genes that confer immunity to multiple pathogens, D. It may provide insight into the evolution of the human genome Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is a current concern regarding the bubonic plague? Options: A. The emergence of a new strain that is highly contagious, B. The development of a vaccine that is not effective against the disease, C. The recent emergence of a drug-resistant strain, D. The lack of funding for research into the disease Correct Option: C
Question 9: How has the threat of an epidemic on the scale of the Black Death been largely eliminated? Options: A. Through the development of vaccines, B. Through improvements in sanitation and hygiene practices, C. Through the use of antibiotics, D. Through changes in human behavior Correct Option: C
Question 10: Why is learning more about the causes and effects of the Black Death important? Options: A. It may help us understand how our world has been shaped by the past, B. It may provide insight into the evolution of the human genome, C. It may help us prevent future pandemics, D. Both A and C Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent (identifying the cause of the Black Death), options (including the correct answer, Yersinia pestis, the bacterium that causes bubonic plague), and content (focusing on the primary cause of the Black Death as revealed by DNA analysis). 

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2.

in your neighborhood, your city, or even your whole country were wiped out. It might sound like something

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 3

**Transcript**:
Imagine if half the people
in your neighborhood, your city, or even your whole country were wiped out. It might sound like something
out of an apocalyptic horror film, but it actually happened 
in the 14th century during a disease outbreak
known as the Black Death. Spreading from China through Asia,
the Middle East, Africa, and Europe, the devastating epidemic destroyed 
as much as 1/5 of the world's population, killing nearly 50% of Europeans
in just four years. One of the most fascinating

humans for centuries. DNA analysis of bone
and tooth samples from this period, as well as an earlier epidemic known
as the Plague of Justinian in 541 CE, has revealed that both were caused
by Yersinia pestis, the same bacterium that causes
bubonic plague today. What this means is that the same disease
caused by the same pathogen can behave and spread 
very differently throughout history. Even before the use of antibiotics,

was so much deadlier must lie not in the parasite but the host. For about 300 years during

throughout Europe. But with so many new mouths to feed, the end of this warm period
spelled disaster. High fertility rates
combined with reduced harvest, meant the land could no longer 
support its population, while the abundant supply of labor
kept wages low. As a result, most Europeans

leaving them vulnerable to infection. And indeed, the skeletal remains
of Black Death victims found in London show telltale signs of

changed humanity in two important ways. On a societal level,

in Europe’s economic conditions. With more food to go around, as well as more land and better pay
for the surviving farmers and workers, people began to eat better and live longer as studies of London cemeteries
have shown. Higher living standards also brought

on the scale of the Black Death has been largely eliminated 
thanks to antibiotics. But the bubonic plague continues to kill a
few thousand people worldwide every year, and the recent emergence
of a drug-resistant strain threatens the return of darker times. Learning more about the causes and effects
of the Black Death is important, not just for understanding how
our world has been shaped by the past. It may also help save us from 
a similar nightmare in the future.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The Black Death was the second major epidemic of its kind. What was the first known epidemic of the disease that also caused the Black Death?
Options: A. The Plague of India, B. The Plague of Justinian, C. The Hong Kong Plague, D. The Antonine Plague
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What percentage of the world's population is estimated to have been destroyed by the Black Death in the 14th century? Options: A. 10%, B. 15%, C. 1/5 (or 20%), D. 25% Correct Option: C

Yersinia pestis, the bacterium that causes bubonic plague, C. A genetic mutation in the human population, D. Poor sanitation and hygiene practices Correct Option: B
Question 3: How did the medieval Black Death likely spread, compared to modern instances of plague? Options: A. Through rodent fleas, B. Directly from one person to another, C. Through contaminated water sources, D. Through airborne transmission Correct Option: B
Question 4: What factor contributed to the rapid spread and high mortality rate of the Black Death in Europe? Options: A. A colder climate, B. Improved agricultural practices, C. High fertility rates combined with reduced harvests, D. Overcrowding in urban areas Correct Option: C
Question 5: What was the impact of the Black Death on the economic conditions in Europe? Options: A. It led to a decline in living standards and increased poverty, B. It resulted in a significant increase in social mobility and weakened feudalism, C. It had no significant impact on the economy, D. It led to a decrease in food production and availability Correct Option: B
Question 6: How did the Black Death affect the gene pool of the surviving population? Options: A. It resulted in a loss of genetic diversity, B. It led to an increase in genetic mutations that conferred immunity to multiple pathogens, C. It had no significant impact on the gene pool, D. It resulted in a decrease in the frequency of genes associated with disease resistance Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is a potential benefit of researching the genetic consequences of the Black Death? Options: A. It may lead to the development of new antibiotics, B. It may provide insight into the evolution of the human genome Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is a current concern regarding the bubonic plague? Options: A. The emergence of a new strain that is highly contagious, B. The development of a vaccine that is not effective against the disease, C. The recent emergence of a drug-resistant strain, D. The lack of funding for research into the disease Correct Option: C

Through improvements in sanitation and hygiene practices, C. Through the use of antibiotics, D. Through changes in human behavior Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Imagine if half the people
in your neighborhood, your city, or even your whole country were wiped out. It might sound like something
out of an apocalyptic horror film, but it actually happened 
in the 14th century during a disease outbreak
known as the Black Death. Spreading from China through Asia,
the Middle East, Africa, and Europe, the devastating epidemic destroyed 
as much as 1/5 of the world's population, killing nearly 50% of Europeans
in just four years. One of the most fascinating
and puzzling things abut the Black Death is that the illness itself
was not a new phenomenon but one that has affected
humans for centuries. DNA analysis of bone
and tooth samples from this period, as well as an earlier epidemic known
as the Plague of Justinian in 541 CE, has revealed that both were caused
by Yersinia pestis, the same bacterium that causes
bubonic plague today. What this means is that the same disease
caused by the same pathogen can behave and spread 
very differently throughout history. Even before the use of antibiotics,
the deadliest oubreaks in modern times, such as the ones that occurred
in early 20th century India, killed no more than 3% of the population. Modern instances of plague
also tend to remain localized, or travel slowly,
as they are spread by rodent fleas. But the medieval Black Death,
which spread like wildfire, was most likely communicated directly
from one person to another. And because genetic comparisons of ancient
to modern strains of Yersinia pestis have not revealed any significantly
functional genetic differences, the key to why the earlier outbreak
was so much deadlier must lie not in the parasite but the host. For about 300 years during
the High Middle Ages, a warmer climate
and agricultural improvements had led to explosive population growth
throughout Europe. But with so many new mouths to feed, the end of this warm period
spelled disaster. High fertility rates
combined with reduced harvest, meant the land could no longer 
support its population, while the abundant supply of labor
kept wages low. As a result, most Europeans
in the early 14th century experienced a steady decline
in living standards, marked by famine, poverty and poor health,
leaving them vulnerable to infection. And indeed, the skeletal remains
of Black Death victims found in London show telltale signs of 
malnutrition and prior illness. The destruction caused by the Black Death
changed humanity in two important ways. On a societal level,
the rapid loss of population led to important changes
in Europe’s economic conditions. With more food to go around, as well as more land and better pay
for the surviving farmers and workers, people began to eat better and live longer as studies of London cemeteries
have shown. Higher living standards also brought
an increase in social mobility, weakening feudalism and eventually
leading to political reforms. But the plague also had an important
biological impact. The sudden death of so many of
the most frail and vulnerable people left behind a population with
a significantly different gene pool, including genes that may have helped
survivors resist the disease. And because such mutations 
often confer immunities to multiple pathogens 
that work in similar ways, research to discover the genetic
consequences of the Black Death has the potential to be hugely beneficial. Today, the threat of an epidemic 
on the scale of the Black Death has been largely eliminated 
thanks to antibiotics. But the bubonic plague continues to kill a
few thousand people worldwide every year, and the recent emergence
of a drug-resistant strain threatens the return of darker times. Learning more about the causes and effects
of the Black Death is important, not just for understanding how
our world has been shaped by the past. It may also help save us from 
a similar nightmare in the future.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What proportion of the affected population was killed by the Black Death?
Options: A. Less than 10%, B. About 25%, C. Over 90%, D. About 50%
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What percentage of the world's population is estimated to have been destroyed by the Black Death in the 14th century? Options: A. 10%, B. 15%, C. 1/5 (or 20%), D. 25% Correct Option: C

Yersinia pestis, the bacterium that causes bubonic plague, C. A genetic mutation in the human population, D. Poor sanitation and hygiene practices Correct Option: B

Question 5: What was the impact of the Black Death on the economic conditions in Europe? Options: A. It led to a decline in living standards and increased poverty, B. It resulted in a significant increase in social mobility and weakened feudalism, C. It had no significant impact on the economy, D. It led to a decrease in food production and availability Correct Option: B
Question 6: How did the Black Death affect the gene pool of the surviving population? Options: A. It resulted in a loss of genetic diversity, B. It led to an increase in genetic mutations that conferred immunity to multiple pathogens, C. It had no significant impact on the gene pool, D. It resulted in a decrease in the frequency of genes associated with disease resistance Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is a potential benefit of researching the genetic consequences of the Black Death? Options: A. It may lead to the development of new antibiotics, B. It may help us understand how to prevent future pandemics, C. It may reveal genes that confer immunity to multiple pathogens, D. It may provide insight into the evolution of the human genome Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is a current concern regarding the bubonic plague? Options: A. The emergence of a new strain that is highly contagious, B. The development of a vaccine that is not effective against the disease, C. The recent emergence of a drug-resistant strain, D. The lack of funding for research into the disease Correct Option: C
Question 9: How has the threat of an epidemic on the scale of the Black Death been largely eliminated? Options: A. Through the development of vaccines, B. Through improvements in sanitation and hygiene practices, C. Through the use of antibiotics, D. Through changes in human behavior Correct Option: C
Question 10: Why is learning more about the causes and effects of the Black Death important? Options: A. It may help us understand how our world has been shaped by the past, B. It may provide insight into the evolution of the human genome, C. It may help us prevent future pandemics, D. Both A and C Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

Although the ground truth MCQ asks about the proportion of the affected population killed by the Black Death, and Question 1 asks about the percentage of the world's population destroyed by the Black Death, both questions are related to the impact of the Black Death in terms of population loss. 

However, it's worth noting that the options and the specific focus of the questions are not identical. The ground truth MCQ focuses on the affected population (i.e., Europeans), while Question 1 looks at the global population. **Transcript**:
Imagine if half the people
in your neighborhood, your city, or even your whole country were wiped out. It might sound like something
out of an apocalyptic horror film, but it actually happened 
in the 14th century during a disease outbreak
known as the Black Death. Spreading from China through Asia,
the Middle East, Africa, and Europe, the devastating epidemic destroyed 
as much as 1/5 of the world's population, killing nearly 50% of Europeans
in just four years. One of the most fascinating
and puzzling things abut the Black Death is that the illness itself
was not a new phenomenon but one that has affected
humans for centuries. DNA analysis of bone
and tooth samples from this period, as well as an earlier epidemic known
as the Plague of Justinian in 541 CE, has revealed that both were caused
by Yersinia pestis, the same bacterium that causes
bubonic plague today. What this means is that the same disease
caused by the same pathogen can behave and spread 
very differently throughout history. Even before the use of antibiotics,
the deadliest oubreaks in modern times, such as the ones that occurred
in early 20th century India, killed no more than 3% of the population. Modern instances of plague
also tend to remain localized, or travel slowly,
as they are spread by rodent fleas. But the medieval Black Death,

from one person to another. And because genetic comparisons of ancient

was so much deadlier must lie not in the parasite but the host. For about 300 years during

and agricultural improvements had led to explosive population growth
throughout Europe. But with so many new mouths to feed, the end of this warm period

combined with reduced harvest, meant the land could no longer 
support its population, while the abundant supply of labor
kept wages low. As a result, most Europeans
in the early 14th century experienced a steady decline
in living standards, marked by famine, poverty and poor health,
leaving them vulnerable to infection. And indeed, the skeletal remains
of Black Death victims found in London show telltale signs of 
malnutrition and prior illness. The destruction caused by the Black Death
changed humanity in two important ways. On a societal level,
the rapid loss of population led to important changes
in Europe’s economic conditions. With more food to go around, as well as more land and better pay
for the surviving farmers and workers, people began to eat better and live longer as studies of London cemeteries
have shown. Higher living standards also brought
an increase in social mobility, weakening feudalism and eventually
leading to political reforms. But the plague also had an important
biological impact. The sudden death of so many of
the most frail and vulnerable people left behind a population with
a significantly different gene pool, including genes that may have helped
survivors resist the disease. And because such mutations 
often confer immunities to multiple pathogens 
that work in similar ways, research to discover the genetic
consequences of the Black Death has the potential to be hugely beneficial. Today, the threat of an epidemic 
on the scale of the Black Death has been largely eliminated 
thanks to antibiotics. But the bubonic plague continues to kill a
few thousand people worldwide every year, and the recent emergence
of a drug-resistant strain threatens the return of darker times. Learning more about the causes and effects
of the Black Death is important, not just for understanding how
our world has been shaped by the past. It may also help save us from 
a similar nightmare in the future.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Check this out: Here's a grid, nothing special,
just a basic grid, very grid-y. But look closer, 
into this white spot at the center where the two central vertical
and horizontal lines intersect. Look very closely.
Notice anything funny about this spot? Yeah, nothing. But keep looking.
Get weird and stare at it. Now, keeping your gaze
fixed on this white spot, check what's happening
in your peripheral vision. The other spots, are they still white?
Or do they show weird flashes of grey? Now look at this pan for baking muffins. Oh, sorry, one of the cups is inverted.
It pops up instead of dipping down. Wait, no spin the pan.
The other five are domed now? Whichever it is, this pan's defective. Here's a photo of Abraham Lincoln,
and here's one upside down. Nothing weird going on here. Wait, turn that upside down one right side up.
What have they done to Abe? Those are just three optical illusions,
images that seem to trick us. How do they work? Are magical things happening
in the images themselves? While we could certainly be
sneaking flashes of grey into the peripheral white spots
of our animated grid, first off, we promise we aren't. You'll see the same effect with a grid
printed on a plain old piece of paper. In reality, this grid really is just a grid.
But not to your brain's visual system. Here's how it interprets the light
information you call this grid. The white intersections are surrounded by 
relatively more white on all four sides than any white point along a line segment. Your retinal ganglion cells notice that
there is more white around the intersections because they are organized to
increase contrast with lateral inhibition. Better contrast means it's easier
to see the edge of something. And things are what your eyes
and brain have evolved to see. Your retinal ganglion cells don't
respond as much at the crossings because there is more lateral inhibition
for more white spots nearby compared to the lines, 
which are surrounded by black. This isn't just a defect in your eyes; if you can see, then optical illusions
can trick you with your glasses on or with this paper or
computer screen right up in your face. What optical illusions show us is the way your photo receptors and brain
assemble visual information into the three-dimensional world
you see around you, where edges should get extra attention because things with edges
can help you or kill you. Look at that muffin pan again.
You know what causes confusion here? Your brain's visual cortex operates on
assumptions about the lighting of this image. It expects light to come from
a single source, shining down from above. And so these shading patterns could only
have been caused by light shining down on the sloping sides of a dome,
or the bottom of a hole. If we carefully recreate these clues
by drawing shading patterns, even on a flat piece of paper, our brain reflexively creates
the 3D concave or convex shape. Now for that creepy Lincoln
upside down face. Faces trigger activity
in areas of the brain that have specifically evolved
to help us recognize faces. Like the fusiform face area and others
in the occipital and temporal lobes. It makes sense, too,
we're very social animals with highly complex ways of
interacting with each other. When we see faces,
we have to recognize they are faces and figure out what
they're expressing very quickly. And what we focus on most
are the eyes and mouth. That's how we figure out if someone
is mad at us or wants to be our friend. In the upside down Lincoln face, the eyes and mouth were
actually right side up, so you didn't notice anything was off. But when we flipped the whole image over,
the most important parts of the face, the eyes and mouth, were now upside down,
and you realized something fishy was up. You realized your brain had taken
a short cut and missed something. But your brain wasn't really being lazy,
it's just very busy. So it spends cognitive energy
as efficiently as possible, using assumptions about visual information
to create a tailored, edited vision of the world. Imagine your brain
calling out these edits on the fly: "Okay, those squares could be objects. Let's enhance that black-white contrast
on the sides with lateral inhibition. Darken those corners! Dark grey fading into light grey? Assume overhead sunlight
falling on a sloping curve. Next! Those eyes look like most eyes I've seen before,
nothing weird going on here." See? Our visual tricks have
revealed your brain's job as a busy director of 3D animation
in a studio inside your skull, allocating cognitive energy and
constructing a world on the fly with tried and mostly -- but not always -- true
tricks of its own.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The connections between neurons in the retina, specifically the connections referred to as “lateral inhibition,” help us see which of the following better?
Options: A. Contrast, B. Faces, C. Colors
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary function of retinal ganglion cells in the visual system? Options: A. To detect colors, B. To transmit visual information from the retina to the brain, C. To increase contrast through lateral inhibition, D. To regulate the amount of light entering the eye Correct Option: C
Question 2: Why is the brain tricked by the muffin pan optical illusion? Options: A. The brain expects light to come from multiple sources, B. The brain expects light to come from a single source, shining down from above, C. The brain is unable to recognize shading patterns, D. The brain relies solely on prior experiences to interpret visual information Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the name of the area in the brain specifically evolved to help recognize faces? Options: A. Fusiform face area, B. Occipital lobe, C. Temporal lobe, D. Cerebral cortex Correct Option: A
Question 4: A researcher wants to study how the brain processes visual information. Which method would be most effective? Options: A. Using a grid printed on a plain old piece of paper to study optical illusions, B. Using a computer screen to study optical illusions, C. Using a combination of both A and B to study optical illusions, D. Using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to study brain activity Correct Option: C
Question 5: Why does the brain take shortcuts when processing visual information? Options: A. The brain is lazy, B. The brain is busy and needs to allocate cognitive energy efficiently, C. The brain is unable to process visual information accurately, D. The brain relies solely on prior experiences to interpret visual information Correct Option: B
Question 6: How does the brain construct a 3D world? Options: A. The brain uses assumptions about visual information to create a tailored, edited vision of the world, B. The brain uses only the information provided by the eyes to construct a 3D world, C. The brain relies solely on prior experiences to interpret visual information, D. The brain uses a combination of visual, auditory, and tactile information to construct a 3D world Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the primary function of lateral inhibition in the visual system? Options: A. To increase contrast, B. To decrease contrast, C. To recognize faces, D. To regulate the amount of light entering the eye Correct Option: A
Question 8: A designer wants to create an optical illusion that tricks the brain into seeing a 3D shape. Which technique would be most effective? Options: A. Using shading patterns to create a 3D shape, B. Using colors to create a 3D shape, C. Using shapes to create a 3D shape, D. Using motion to create a 3D shape Correct Option: A
Question 9: Why is the brain able to recognize faces quickly? Options: A. The brain has specifically evolved areas to recognize faces, B. The brain is able to recognize faces because of the eyes and mouth, C. The brain relies solely on prior experiences to recognize faces, D. The brain uses a combination of visual and auditory information to recognize faces Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the main idea of the transcript? Options: A. Optical illusions are a result of the brain's inability to process visual information accurately, B. The brain is lazy and takes shortcuts when processing visual information, C. The brain uses assumptions and tricks to construct a 3D world, D. The brain relies solely on prior experiences to interpret visual information Correct Option: C
Question 11: What is the role of the visual cortex in processing visual information? Options: A. To detect colors, B. To recognize shapes, C. To interpret visual information based on assumptions about lighting and shading, D. To regulate the amount of light entering the eye Correct Option: C
Question 12: Why are edges important in visual perception? Options: A. Because they help the brain recognize shapes, B. Because they help the brain detect colors, C. Because they help the brain interpret visual information and detect potential threats or objects, D. Because they help the brain regulate the amount of light entering the eye Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions ask about the role of lateral inhibition in the visual system, and both have options related to contrast, which is the correct answer.
